div3.head: Secession abroad: -- great excitement on account of the tariff — Europe speaking out :
div3.p:
In spite of their abolition proclivities, the English journals are out in full cry upon the Morrill. tariff, and warn the North that if it is not repealed, it will bring odium and ruin upon the Republican States.
They assure the anti-slavery journals of the free States, that though the abolition scruples of England are the result of conscientous conviction, yet they cannot, as sensible English-men, permit their consciences to interfere with their trade, an assurance which, to one tolerably familiar with history, is quite supererogatory.
The Liverpool Mercury declares that "Northern Protectionism& is as bad as &Southern Secession.& It says the new tariff bill &is about the most retrograde piece of legislation that any country, within the Old or the New World has seen of date years,& and that &its object appears to be to reduce to a minimum the foreign trade of the Northern Union.
The Republican party, while it strongly claims our sympathies on one all-essential point, is committed to the nonsensical dogmas of compulsion and exploded political economy. ""It is certain that either protectionists tariffs or the Federal Union will have to give way. It is unfortunate for the North that the advocacy of sound economical principles should be almost exclusively confined to slave-owners and their sympathizers, and that Mr. Jefferson Davis should talk like a statesman and a man of sense on a subject on which Mr.Lincoln discourses like an Essex squire of the corn law and top-boot epoch."

The London Times adds its deep-toned sayings to the general thunders of denunciation from Europe.
It openly advocates the policy of President Davis, and avows its belief that the commerce of the North will be destroyed by the Morrill tariff.
It says:

q.p:
"If Americans wish to know with what feelings this measure has been regarded in England, they have only to turn to the Trade Reports of The Times, and their curiosity will be gratified.
Thus we find from Birmingham that a hardware and cutlery trade of 3,800,000.
is looked upon as worthless.
South Staffordshire is in dismay. 'The conduct of Congress on the Tariff Bill has much changed the tone of public feeling with reference to the Secessionists, and none here, even those whose sympathies are with the Northern States, attempt to justify the course which the Protectionists in Congress have pursued.' In Manchester the proposed increase of duties on cotton goods in the United States is causing great attention-- in Newcastle it is considered that it will be impossible to do business with the United States on the terms set out in the Tariff, while the business with the Southern States is described as satisfactory.
In Sheffield considerable apprehension is felt as to the effect of the new tariff on the steel trade.
In Wolverhampton the anticipation that the Tariff has become law darkens the already gloomy prospects of the iron trade.-- In that respect it has done its worst, but it is destined.
if we mistake not, to be the fruitful mother of other disruptions.
What interest have the great agricultural Western States, for instance, in being made tributaries to the iron-masters of Pennsylvania, or the cotton-spinners of Lowell?
They will desire, as the South have desired, a direct trade with England, and the peculiar position of Canada, with its facilities of communication by lake, river, and railway, will show them the readiest means of obtaining a direct trade by a fresh separation — possibly by an amalgamation with our own colonies.

" These topics are so obvious that we forbear to insist upon them, but we beg to point out, for the comfort of our own countrymen and the warning of the Government of the United States, that in attempting to exclude at one blow twenty millions of exports from their territory, they have undertaken a task quite beyond their power.-- They may, indeed, destroy their own Customs' revenue; they may give additional strength to these vested interests which claim a prescriptive right to live on the vitals of the community; they may ruin the shipping and cripple the commerce of the towns on the Atlantic seaboard, but they cannot prevent English manufactures from permeating the United States from one end to the other.
A glance at the map is sufficient to show this.
The Southern Confederacy will, of course, desire no better than to make Charleston, Savannah, Mobile and New Orleans, depots for English manufactures, to be smuggled across the long and imperceptible frontier which separates them from the United States.-- Nay, it is quite possible that the great city of New York may prefer to declare itself a free port, and to become the depot of an illicit traffic, rather than see its wharves rotting, its streets deserted, and its harbors empty, because a suicidal folly has driven commerce to the inferior harbors of the South.
The indented coasts of the Northern states give ample opportunity for smuggling, and, what is still more important, the frontier between Canada and the Union is virtually traced by the stream of the St. Lawrence and the centre of the great Lakes Ontario, Erie, and Huron.
It is a region which might have been created for the express purpose of punishing the presumptions folly of seeking to erect the barrier of prohibition between nations which have long enjoyed the mutual benefits of commercial intercourse.
The smuggler will redress the errors of the statesman, as he has so often done before.
The change may occasion delay, loss, and inconvenience; but the stream is too mighty to be choked, and no sooner will the old channel have been stopped than a new one will be forced."

div3.p: Even the London News, the organ of Exeter Hall, says:

q.p:
"Mr, Gregory has given notice that on an early day he will call the attention of her Majesty's Government to the expediency of a prompt recognition of the Southern Confederacy of America.--There is no occasion for Mr. Gregory or any one else to be anxious to get our Government to acknowledge the so-called Southern Confederacy of American States.
The practice of the British Government.
in such cases, is firmly established, and well understood-- viz: to recognize all defacto Governments, irrespective of opinions, origin, or any circumstance but the fact of being the actually established ruling power.
If ever, and whenever, that happens with the Southern States, which now profess to be a Confederacy, there can be no doubt, about their being recognized by all the European powers; and by England with the utmost certainty and distinctness-- but the case has not yet reached this stage; and it is very far from reaching it."

div3.p:
The people of France, our ancient and chivalric ally, lead the way in welcoming the new Confederacy into the confraternity of nations.
The Moniteur, the official journal of the Imperial Government, has expressed the "deepest indignation at the increase of duties imposed by the Northern States upon French productions," and the Pays has loudly proclaimed: "Let the independence of the South be recognized.
In the hands of Northern men, the edifice, which was raised with so much care and labor by their predecessors, comes crashing down, threatening to carry with it, in its fall, the industrial future of every other nation, "
The Weser-Zeitung, of Bremen, says:

q.p:
"The political crisis in the United States has gradually reached a point, after which all constitutional discussions are utterly superfluous.--The seceded States may have had ever so little right to revolt against the Federal Government; their revolution is no less a fixed fact, which sound policy will have to treat according to principles different from those of the Supreme Court at Washington.
This is not the first instance in history where an indubitable wrong claims to be treated on the same footing with rights and institutions that have existed for centuries.
The reality of life never fails from time to time to produce such claims, against which the moral sentiment of a nation at first invariably revolts; but sooner or later the moment arrives, where it becomes unreasonable and impracticable to limit the development of nations to the rigid formula of written law, and to judge of its changes as we judge of a question of civil law.

"This one-sided point of view is speedily overcome and put to rest, where — as in the new world — the origin and growth of the existing Constitution does not date back into immemorial and venerated ages, but where this process has been gone through as the visible and tangible work of men, before the eyes, as it were of a generation still living and in the sober daylight of modern times The Constitution of the United States is a compromise, the record of which lies before us in legible detail, in the modern and intelligible English of the eighteenth century; every body knows that it is not the mysterious result of the unconscious growth of a thousand years, but the product of very prosaic and prudent calculations, which were based upon clearly defined interests, where questions of finance, of administration, of personal security and security of property, played almost an exclusive part.
Questions very similar to those brought to bear on the formation of the U.S. Constitution, are to-day operating in an opposite direction for its destruction; and it ought therefore not to surprise us, that the support which the state of things heretofore existing receives from more ideal views of men and from the sentiment of national and fraternal veneration is extremely weak.
The greatest political question which has ever agitated the public life of the Union, presents itself essentially as a question of dollars and cents; and it is characteristic that since the breaking out of the crisis the discussion turns mostly on such points as these: How about the Custom-Houses?
how about the post-offices?
the national debt?
the property in the navy and armories?
We observe very little of the convulsions of a wounded nationality — such, for instance, as vibrate to this day in the heart of Poland; although Poland perished before the American Union was born.
To be sure there is no lack of animosity and passion, but it is an animosity more like that existing between quarrelling partners in business, than that between divided brethren.

"This sober, business-like character of the contest, we think, favors a final settlement of the question.
To the Polish we may prove ever so clearly that they fare better under the Prussian Government than they ever did before, that their property is more valuable, their security greater, their rights better protected than during the time of their national independence, that their political death has been a social and economical benefit to them; they will nevertheless hail with enthusiasm the moment which promises the restoration of their old Polish liberty and barbarism.
The Americans are following a train of thought quite opposite.
Let them be convinced that a dissolution of the Union will bring no great injury to their material interests, and they will accept the fact of secession, and employ their energies to make the most of a new state of things.
If the free States were of opinion that, by the secession of the slave states, their commerce, their agriculture and industry would receive a deadly blow, they would certainly risk everything, and, if necessary, invade the South in order to maintain the Union.
If on the contrary, cool reflection proves, as we think it does, that such dangers are not necessarily connected with a separation of the States; that commerce and trade are more powerful than political boundaries; that civil war costs a great deal of money, besides blood; that a triumph of the North over the South would, at best, be a barren satisfaction, and could never, really and truly, heal the rupture which an armed conflict could only increase; then, we believe, these States will think twice before they fire the first cannon for such an object."

div3.p:
From the beginning, the Dispatch has predicted that the manufacturing interests of Europe would override its pretended abolition philanthropy, and compel it to recognize the independence of the Southern States.
We thank heaven that we were never stupid enough to believe that the abolitionism of the Old World had anything in it honest, sincere and humane.
When slavery existed in their own colonies, they were such despotic taskmasters that insurrection was the rule instead of the exception.
But the interests of nations, which are their only conscience, leave Europe no alternative but to use Southern cotton, and keep open the Southern ports.
Truly, never was a people so favored by Providence as the people of the Southern Confederacy.
The commercial world lies at their feet, and if they use their great advantages with a grateful and humble recognition of the source from which they are derived, and with the wisdom and moderation which have marked the organization of their Government, they will become the wealthiest and happiest people the world has ever seen.

div3.head:
The Episcopal Church and the National
troubles.
div3.p:
The New York Church Journal states that there will be no schismatical division of the Episcopal Church in consequence of the separation of the Confederacy.
In the organization of that Church each State composes a Diocese, and each Diocese, like each State, is sovereign and independent.
Their national organization resembles the Federal organization, and consequently, according to the Journal, not only will the effects of State secession upon the diocesan relations of the Church in the seceded States be at once recognized, but where, as in the case of the Bishopric of Alabama, the concurrence of the National Episcopate may be necessary to fill a vacancy, the promptest measures will be taken by the Northern Bishops to give the requisite sanction to the elections in Alabama, and to every other act necessary for the entire independence of all the dioceses in the seceded States.
This is in perfect harmony with the noble attitude of the Episcopal Church in the North from the beginning, which has always and everywhere set its face as a flint against abolitionism, and every other ism, and which is composed of a body of clergy and laity which would have done honor to any age and any nation of the Christian Church.

div3.head: Letter from a Virginian in the North.
div3.p:
The following extract from a Virginian gentleman residing in Philadelphia, to his correspondent in this city, will be read with interest.
It will be seen that the Northern people are getting ahead of our own Unionists, in discovering that the Union is dissolved:

div4.p:
Your favor of the 23d came promptly to hand.
You are in error, however, in supposing that the Northern people are still laboring under the hallucination that the cotton States are still in the Union.
They admit it — it is true reluctantly — and I believe a majority have come to the conclusion that a peaceable separation is the only course to be pursued in the present aspect of affairs.
Some of the leading politicians oppose it at present, but so soon as the patronage of the Government is apportioned out among these cormorants, they will accept any terms offered them.
If Virginia would pass a secession ordinance, and unite with the South, the most stable prosperous, and powerful Government could be formed on the face of the globe.

"If the members of the Convention knew the condition of things here and elsewhere in the North.
as I know them, they would not hesitate an hour.
Oh! Virginia, the mother of statesmen, heroes and patriots, there was at me when your absent sons could point with proud satisfaction to you, as a model of honor, chivalry, and decision of character, but you have fallen from your proud estate into the lap of the moderate republicans.
Nothing but a withdrawal of the Border Slave States will settle this question, and the sooner it is done the better."

div3.head: The Legislature.
div3.p:
On Saturday the Senate voted on and rejected the bill to aid the Covington and Ohio Railroad.
The vote was afterwards reconsidered and the bill laid on the table.
The resolution favoring the establishment of a line of packet between France and Virginia, was adopted.
The General Appropriation bill was passed; also Senate bill for the relief of the Orange and Alexandria railroad, as amended by the House, and a number of local bills.
At the night session, the joint resolution for the relief of the securities of P. P. Winston, late Sheriff of Richmond, was laid on the table.-- In Executive session, C. Dimmock was confirmed as Colonel of Ordnance; B.G. Baldwin as Captain of do., and P. G. Coghlan as Clerk of do.

The House, at its morning session, passed a number of bills, mostly originating in the Senate, and postponed indefinitely the consideration of Senate amendment rescinding Monday as the time of final adjournment, and fixing on Thursday.
The House joint resolution in regard to the movement of Federal troops and arms within this State, with Senate amendments thereto, was considered and debated at some length.
At the night session discussion was resumed, and continued in one way or another till 4½ o'clock yesterday morning, when the House began to vote on certain amendments, one of which, offered by Mr. Collier, striking out that part of the Senate resolution requiring the Governor to call out the militia, was adopted about 5 o'clock; shortly after that time, a quorum having been obtained, the Senate amendment to House resolution passed.
They were published on Friday.

div3.head: The Convention.
div3.p:
The debate was continued on Saturday, in Committee of the Whole, on the pending propositions.
Mr. Flournoy urged the presenting of an ultimatum to the North, without a Conference with the Border States.
Mr. Goggin spoke in favor of his own ordinance of secession, which looks to a re-construction in union with the States which-have withdrawn.
Mr. James Barbour commenced a speech, advocating secession, but was physically unable to finish.
He will resume the floor to-day, if the state of his health permits.
The Convention, after a pretty warm contest, adopted a resolution for the termination of debate, in Committee of the Whole, on Thursday next.

div3.head: [special correspondence of the Dispatch.]
div3.p: Our city is full of strangers (the Convention being again in session,) and a world of merchants.

In the Convention to-day a pretty sharp debate sprung up, growing out of the secret ses -sion resolution, in which debate some severe strictures were made upon the new Constitu- tion, upon that clause admitting other States into the Confederacy.
The fear seems to be that the non-slaveholding States will seek to annex themselves to the new Confederation, to which South Carolina is decidedly opposed — and, in my judgment, rightfully.
A non- slaveholding State ought never to be admitted, and if possible to prevent it, several slave States might be dispensed with.
My fear is now that our Constitution will be adopted by the Black Republican Government of America, and that that people will become so docile that they will be allowed to come into society again, to which every decent man ought to enter his protest.

The Black Republican Government has certainly been considerate of us, in the adop- tion of their new tariff bill.
If they had searched the world over, they could not have pitched upon any measure more to their own injury and our prosperity.
Already capital is flowing here and all parts of the Confederation, establishing houses, and by next fall you will see here some of the largest dry goods and other importing houses in the land.
A joint stock company, of immense capital, is now being organized here, to open a leather and shoe business, and I hear of one of the richest New York houses establishing a house in Macon, Ga., and by fall we shall be able to sell all the goods wanted by the people of the South, at full 15 per cent.--perhaps twenty-- below Northern prices.

Your Government seems to be in a dilemma as to Fort Moultrie.
They wish to send a war steamer to take off Major Anderson, but Gov. Pickens and Gen. Beauregard refuse to let one of their steamers come into our harbor.
If they wish the Major to be con- veyed away in a war steamer, she may lie outside, and the Governor will direct a private steamer to convey the garrison to her; or the Major and his men may, if they prefer, have a steamer belonging to our port call and take him to New York; or they may have a safe passage through the city.
The object of the party is evidently to throw the responsibility of the evacuation upon Major Ander- son; hence, they wish him to request that his Government may order him away.
He will never leave until he is ordered, if he starves, nor will we let him leave without it is done by Lincoln and his Cabinet.
The fact is, they are now put to their wits' end, and "a little more grape" and they will succumb entirely, for they are in inextricable difficulties already, and every lunge they make sinks them but the deeper.

Palmetto is in demand in your State.
Almost every day brings an order for one, di- rected to "Virginius," in terms complimentary to both Carolina and Virginius himself.-- Some of these correspondents take me to be a Carolinian, and others a Virginian, but I reckon when I tell them that I am an Englishman they will be surprised.
The Palmettoes "Virginius" has not yet sent, and he wishes to make an apology to these correspondents through your paper, and it is this: that he is very busy, all of his helps being in the army, but that he will get a confidential friend to procure these mementoes and send them as early as possible.
I have also received letters from some of the best merchants in your State, making certain inquiries as to business, some having determined, in the Fall, to come here to buy goods.

The weather is perfectly delightful.
We have almost every variety of early vegetables in our market, and "Virginius," and "Mrs. Virginius," and all the little "Virginiuses," feast daily on tomatoes.

Would you not like to have a hamper of green peas, asparagus, tomatoes, and a few strawberries?
Ah! well you may smack your chops.
This is "Good Friday," a day generally observed here as a holiday, but as your hum- ble servant keeps only one day holy, (the Sabbath,) he will feel no compunctions in dropping you a line.

Letters are constantly being received here from your State, asking what is the duty on various articles.
I give you the duty on several most used from your State, for the infor- mation of all interested.
Manufactured tobacco, 30 per cent; leaf tobacco, 24 per cent.; liquors of all kinds, 30 per cent.; coals of all kinds, 15 per cent.; smoking tobacco, (not cut up,) 24 per cent.; smoking tobacco, (cut up by machinery,) 30 per cent.; rail iron-wheels, and all railroad fastenings, 15 per cent.; fire-arms, ordinance, projectiles, ammunition, &c., free; grain of all kinds, flour, and all kinds of feed, made of grain, free.

Revenue stations and officers are placed on every road leading into the Confederacy, to examine trunks of all travelers and all packages to prevent smuggling.
Travelers would do well, and prevent delay and annoyance, by carrying as little baggage as possible, and let it be convenient for examination, and be sure to take nothing along in their trunks dutia- ble, and if they do, let it be where it can be at once seen, and have an invoice of the same and gold enough to pay the duty.
And above all, let them keep their tempers.
A Southern trader thought, a few days ago, he would be smart, and shipped his goods from New York to Wilmington, N. C., and from thence by railroad to Alabama, but they were nabbed in this State, and he will have to pay duty and get delay also.

It is said positively that a dispatch has been received to-day in the city for the long-delayed evacuation; but I shall believe it when I see the Confederate flag flying over the battle- ments of Sumter.
That it will take place, I am sure; but when, is not certain.

I don't believe I have told you that the Secretary of the gallant Col. Lamon, who hailed from your State, but really belonging to Illinois, the envoy extraordinary of the Rail Splitter, was arrested and jailed here on account of an old tailor's bill, made years ago with one of our merchant tailors.
To-morrow the Convention visits the forts and batteries, and will have a grand time of it.

I see that some of the most rebid Black Republican papers (the Boston Advertiser for one,) are pitching into Lincoln already for a too dexterous use of the guillotine.
I see also that some of the Federal Black Republican offices are being filled in your city — bad wind that blows nobody any good.

Who will be Postmaster of your city?
An Old Liner, I suppose, of course.
I wish you would intercede for your friend "Virginius" for some good fat office in this city; he might be stopped in making fire his chief diet.
Do write Abraham, and tell him this is one of his provinces, and "Virginius " is one of his children, and to please let him get hold of the teat.
The fear is, however, that the old cow has gone dry, and however hard I may draw, the milk won't come.

How is it that all the women of your State are secessionists?
A lady writes to " Vir- ginius" that she had rather come South and pick cotton than remain under Black Republican rule.
Many such letters come to " Virginius, correspondent of the Richmond Dis- patch," from which I judge the ladies generally read the Dispatch. I have heard Vir- ginia so highly extolled for her gallantry and patriotism, that I have often thought I should like to have been born on her soil; but I begin now to think that I care not so much about it, and content myself with my own nativity.
But Virginia.
I think, will be right after a while, and so we will wait and see.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
affairs in late of Wight.
div3.p:
Our citizens are growing restless and impatient at the continued inaction of the Con- vention, and the secession furor is rapidly increasing in intensity.
A great revolution has taken place in public sentiment, and had the election been deferred until now, it would doubtless have resulted in the endorsement of a more active policy than that sustained by our representative.
He, however, was sustained as a secessionist, in the event of a failure in the Peace Congress; and should he now decline to support an Ordinance of Seces- sion, he will doubtless both disappoint and misrepresent his constituents.

Many of our best citizens are seriously contemplating a removal to the Confederate States, and your correspondent has heard of several who have already expressed an unal- terable determination to pay no more taxes in Virginia as an integer of the present dis- jointed Union.
Should the Old Dominion long persist in remaining in her present de- graded position, or an ad valorem system of taxation be decided upon, a large proportion of our slaveholding population will undoubtedly be driven South ward.

Our patriotic little county is steadily preparing for the worst, come when or in whatsoever phase it may. The arms, for which an appropriation was some time since made, have been procured, and are, I suppose, ready for distribution.
We have now three well-organized and efficient volunteer corps, admirably officered, and well drilled and equipped, con- stituting an arm of defence of which any county might well be proud.

Speculations are already being made as to the result of the Congressional campaign.-- Much dissatisfaction exists among the former adherents of Gen. Millson, and a desperate effort will be made to defeat him. Among those whose names I have heard suggested as his opponents are Messrs. Wise, Chamblias, and Kindred; though it is announced that the former will accept of no position in the present Federal Government.

Our farmers are busily preparing for the ensuing crop, their operations having been re- tarded by the inclement season.
Fruit, it is thought, will be unusually scarce, especially peaches, plums and cherries.
Flora is again decking the earth with flowers, and yet our ice-houses are all empty.
Where shall we go for this indispensable luxury, if our relations with the North are intercepted?

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
letter from Mississippi.
div3.p:
The Mississippi State Convention meets to-day at Jackson, upon the call of its President, for the purpose of acting upon the permanent Constitution adopted at Montgomery for the government of the Confederate States of the South.
Three States have already ratified it, and this will do likewise in the course of this week, or the next at farthest.
No doubt the submission papers will send up to Heaven (it will never reach there!) a cry against the assumption of the several State Conventions for acting upon the question without reference to a vote of the people.
I beg these learned sources to inform the public whether the Con- stitution of the late Union was submitted to a vote of the people in a single State?
If they do not know, I certainly can inform them that Conventions of the separate States, and not the people direct, adopted that Constitution.
Be assured that if the sentiment of the people of the other States interested is but the half as well represented as is that of this State, it would be no act of love on their part to now ask them to do what they have delegated to faithful exponents the power to do for them.
In the Convention of Louisiana there were but seven dissenting votes to the ratification of the Constitution, and several of these were given upon grounds not at all pertinent to the question.
My reason for speaking of this matter is to show how utterly absurd it is for those living in the Border States to longer en- tertain the idea of reconstruction.
These people say, and say rightly, that the time of dif- ference between them and the North is not the imaginary line of Mason and Dixon, but is one drawn by the Deity, through the very hearts of the people themselves, of the two sections, making them different in almost everything, language included.
It is then the question, (reconstruction impossible)--"Which side will Virginia take?" She may prescribe Federal nostrums, through the Union Doctors of the Convention, until doomsday, but the disease of disunion has assumed a chronic turn which will defy any remedy that can now be administered for it. There can be union, it is true, but it must and will be a union of the South, let the political quacks at Mechanics' Hall do what they may, to the contrary not withstanding.--There is vitality still left in the Old Dominion, and it will not be long, in my opinion, before it is seen in the upheaving of the masses, who, slow to move, will prove they would rather be the equals of Southern brothers than the slaves of Yankee masters.
There is hardly a circumstance of importance con- cerning Virginia politics not familiarly known in the South, so much interested are the peo- ple in what is going on in that State.
Indeed, the old mother seems still greatly loved and venerated by these, her expatriated children, who believe that the cycle of her glory is not yet complete.
They contend, however, that she will not and cannot be unmindful of the high destiny which awaits her as the head of the family of Confederate States.
In my heart of hearts I pray that she may not disappoint not only these people, but those noble and liberty-loving children of the old mother, who, like the gallant King of France, of old, prefer death to such dishonor as political interiority imposes upon them.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
Lincoln burnt in Effigy in Nelson county,
Virginia.
div3.p:
Yesterday was quite an enthusiastic time.
The students at Dr. Gessner Harrison's, created an image in the likeness of old Abe — at least in height — for he was nearly six feet four, and having well saturated his internal arrangements with Kerosine oil, straddled him across the old familiar rail; while the students, with torch lights, proceeded on either side, in the — not very solemn — but numerous procession, and thus rode him to his place of annihilation, where they held him up, and applied the torch.
In a moment, he was in a perfect blaze, and the large sheet of flame rolling and plunging into higher air, lighted the place for some distance around, until the old mauler lay a heap of rubbish, and finally three groans were offered, and given to his ashes.

div3.head:
Correspondence of the Richmond Dispatch.
secession flag on William and Mary, &c.
div3.p:
The students of the college of William and Mary hoisted a secession flag on the top of the college building on the night of the 27th inst., amid the shouts and applause of the whole body.
The spirit of secession was unanimous.
The hearts of all are with the South, and if coercion is commenced, they will undoubtedly resist it to the last, in defence of the liberties and rights of the Southern Confederacy.
The flag consists of three stripes, the two outer of which are red, and the one in the middle is white, and one corner is blue, containing seven stars.
After the flag was hoisted, they fired a cannon seven times in honor of the seven noble and gallant States of the South who have declared their rights and are ready to maintain them.

--Lemuel Shaw, late Chief Justice of Massachusetts, died Saturday morning at his residence, Mt.
Vernon street. He fell dead while conversing and being in the act of dressing himself in his room.
He has lately been in feeble health.

div3.head:
Later from Europe.
arrival of the Africa.
div3.p:
--The steamship Africa, from Liverpool 16th inst., via Queens- town 17th, arrived last night.
She brings £84,000 sterling in specie.
Bullion in the Rank of England had increased £250,000.
The Duchess of Kent (the Queen's mother,) is dangerously ill.
The London Times ridicules the idea of the Confederate States effecting a loan, after Mississippi's repudiation.
Commercial.

Liverpool, March 16th. --Cotton — Sales of the week 58,000 bales, including 9,500 to speculators, and 11,000 to exporters.
The market opened slightly lower, but subsequently recovered under Ameri- can advices, and closed firm at last week's quotations.
The estimated sales of Friday were 15,000 bales, including 7,000 for speculation and export.

Liverpool, March 17.--The estimated sales yesterday were 25,000 bales, including 8,000 for specula- tion and export; stock in port 907,000 bales, of which 750,000 are American.
Hewitt's circular reports the market as closing buoyant, and fully 1/2 higher.
Flour quiet and steady.
Wheat firm.
Corn a shade higher.
Sugar buoyant.
Breadstuffs firm, and prices generally unchanged.
Provisions generally quiet.
Consols 92@92 1/2.

div3.head: From Denver city.
div3.p: Fort Kearny, March 28.--The Western stage, with mails and passengers, and Hinckley's Express, for Omaha, passed here at 4 P. M.

Denver, March 25.--The daily yield of gold in the mines is very rapidly increasing.
The mills are nearly all getting to work, many of them with the new gold-saving process.

The population on the Blue Rim slope has doubled in the last month.
That district will be a great theatre of gold mining operations.

The road over the snowy range, between the South and Middle Forks, is open for pack ani- mals, but not for wagons.
Emigrants from the States are beginning to arrive.
The weather is very fine.

div3.head: Kansas Legislature.
div3.p:
Leavenworth, March 29--The lower House of the Kansas Legislature organized on the 28th, by the election of U. P. DeGraff (Rep.) Speaker.
He is understood to favor Messrs. Parrott and Lane for U. S. Senators.

Gov. Robinson's message is mainly devoted to local affairs.
He recommends suitable acknowledgment by the Legislature for the generous relief given the needy citizens of Kansas.
He recommends also that the credit of the State be used for the relief of her citizens it necessary.
He says that seed has been furnished in abundance for planting purposes, and hopes a general call for relief will soon cease.

div3.head:
Reinforcing Southern forts with Federal
troops--Indian Depredations in Texas.
div3.p: New York, March 31.--The steamship Daniel Webster reports that she landed at Fort Jefferson, Tortugas, Companies L and M, first artillery, and at Fort Taylor, Key West, Companies F and K of the same regiment.

She reports that the Indians are committing great havoc among the people of Texas, kill- ing some, and running off their stock.
Maj. Libbey had chastised some of the savages.
Cortenas was understood to be awaiting the departure of troops to commence operations on a larger scale than heretofore.

div3.head: From Washington.
div3.p: Washington, March 31.--The Commissioners of the Confederate States now here, feel no uneasiness in regard to the evacuation of Fort Sumter or the reinforcement of Fort Pickens, being fully satisfied in regard to both points, and are aiming to achieve a peaceful solution of the difficulties by a speedy withdrawal of troops from the Federal limits within the Confederacy.

div3.head: Affairs in Norfolk.
div3.p: Norfolk, March 30th.--A petition, numerously signed, instructing the representative of this city in the Convention to vote for immediate secession, is in circulation here.

At a large and enthusiastic meeting held last night, resolutions were adopted, instruct- ing Mr. Blow to vote for immediate secession; and delegates were appointed to the Convention to be held on the 19th instant, in Suffolk.
Secession candidates were nominated for Congress.

div3.head: Troops for Pensacola.
div3.p:
Memphis, March 27.--Five hundred Mississippi troops passed through here en route to join the Southern army at Pensacola to-day.
They had a military reception, and were enthusiastically welcomed.

div3.head: Northern Markets.
div3.p:
New York, March 30.--Flour is heavy — sales of 8,500 barrels at a decline of 6--State $5.20@5.20; Ohio $5.37 1/2@5.45; Southern $5.50@5.75.
Wheat is depressed — sales of 12,000 bushels--Western red $1.35@1.36.
Corn is depressed — sales of 10,000 bushels — new mixed 63 Pork is steady — mess unchanged; prime $12.50. Lard is unchanged-- sales at former rates.
